Indicator_series: Urban_Share_in_OPS is the percentage share of urban area occupied by open public spaces (OPS)
Urban_Share_in_Streets is the percentage share of urban area occupied by streets, also known as the land allocated to streets (LAS)
Urban_Share_in_OPS_and_Streets is the combined percentage share of urban area occupied by open public spaces and streets
Population_with_OPS_access is the percentage share of urban population who can access an open public space within a walking distance of 400 meters along the street network

An open public space (OPS) is defined as an area that openly and freely accessible space for all (without any cost implication) for enjoyment of social services such as recreation. Identification of open public spaces is  based on data compiled from city land use plans and open sources including OpenStreetMap and GoogleEarth.

Data used to estimate population with access to open public spaces is based on grid level population disaggregation directly from city/country data, or from the HRSL (facebook and CIESIN) and WorldPop. Analysis year is 2020.

City/urban area used in the analyis has been generated using a classification approach based on the Urban Extent or the Degree of Urbanization concepts to city definition. As a result, the urban/city area used for the indicator computation in this data table may be larger or smaller than the official municipality boundaries. Exception for this is in Peru, Israel and Iceland where data provided by the National Statistical Office is mostly based on official municipal / city boundaries.
Source: United Nations Human Settlement Programme (UN-Habitat), Global Urban Indicators Database 2021

Indicator_Description: Average share of the built-up area of cities that is open space for public use for all, by sex, age and persons with disabilities

Estimate_Source: National Institute of Statistics and Informatics, Peru
